bestBHT.bht: The officers of the ship, detected by St. Luke's nautical skill, attempted to escape under a pretense of carrying anchors ahead of the ship. However, St. Paul, with great presence of mind, thwarted their plan by realizing that they needed the boat to stretch out the anchors in front. The sailors' attempt to flee was due to their belief in the ship's imminent danger, despite the anchors already cast out. St. Paul's wise admonishment prevented them from casting themselves away in an uncertain escape.

Henry Alford: We hear, in a case mentioned by Appian, of anchors being laid out from both ends of a ship.
Carried anchors out of the foreship.
Because in this case they would carry out the anchors to the extent of the cable which was loosened.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: This could have been of no advantage in the circumstances, and as the pretext could not deceive a seaman
we must infer that the officers of the ship were parties to the unworthy attempt
which was perhaps detected by the nautical skill of St. Luke, and communicated by him to St. Paul
Albert Barnes: They pretended that it was necessary to get into the boat, and carry the anchors ahead of the ship so as to make it secure, but with a real intention to make for the shore.
They resolved to escape to a place of safety as soon as possible.
Marvin Vincent: The meaning is, to carry out an anchor to a distance from the prow by means of the small boat.
John Calvin: The grace of the Holy Spirit appeareth in Paul, even in this point also, in that he did wisely admonish that the mariners should not be suffered to fly.

God doth not commend his power to the faithful, that they may give themselves to sluggishness and carelessness, contemning means, or rashly cast away themselves when there is some certain way to escape.
When God appointeth this or that means to bring any thing to pass, he holdeth all men’s senses, that they may not pass the bounds which he hath appointed.
Philip Schaff: They had already lowered it down from the davits, when St. Paul perceived their purpose, and with great presence of mind frustrated it in the most sagacious way.
Under colour as though they would have cast anchor out of the foreship. No more plausible excuse could be given to the passengers.
It was impossible to know whether the four anchors at the stern would hold; and the ship would be made more steady by putting out additional anchors at the bow.
Archibald T. Robertson: Under colour (προφασε). Possibly the same word as 'prophecy,' but here pretence, pretext.
The use here is an old one and appears also in Mark 12:40; Luke 20:47; 1 Thessalonians 2:5; Philippians 1:18.
Note here εκτεινειν (lay out, stretch out) rather than ριψαντες (casting) in verse Acts 27:29, for they pretended to need the small boat to stretch out or lay out the anchors in front.
John Gill: To save their lives, concluding that it was in the utmost danger, and that it would quickly, notwithstanding the anchors cast out, break away, and fall upon the rocks, and split to pieces.

Their pretence in attempting to get out of the ship, and into the boat, was, that whereas there were anchors cast out of the stern, or hinder part of the ship, so they would cast out others, from the fore part of it; and 'stretch' them 'out', as the word signifies, or carry them further out into the sea, for the security of the ship.
And to do which, it was necessary to use the boat.
John Wesley: The sailors were attempting to flee out of the ship — Supposing the boat would go more safely over the shallows.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this particular situation, the officers of the ship, perhaps detected by the nautical skill of St. Luke and communicated by him to St. Paul, had an unworthy attempt to escape to a place of safety under pretense. They pretended that it was necessary to carry the anchors ahead of the ship to make it secure, but their real intention was to flee. However, with great presence of mind, St. Paul foiled their plan, knowing that it was necessary to use the boat to stretch out or lay out the anchors in front. The sailors' attempt to flee out of the ship, while pretending to provide security, was due to their belief that the ship was in the utmost danger and would quickly break away and split.

The officers of the ship, detected by St. Luke's nautical skill, attempted to escape under a pretense of carrying anchors ahead of the ship. However, St. Paul, with great presence of mind, thwarted their plan by realizing that they needed the boat to stretch out the anchors in front. The sailors' attempt to flee was due to their belief in the ship's imminent danger, despite the anchors already cast out. St. Paul's wise admonishment prevented them from casting themselves away in an uncertain escape.

The officers of the ship, revealed by St. Luke's nautical skill, deceitfully planned to escape under the guise of carrying anchors ahead of the ship. Cunningly, St. Paul saw through their pretext and foiled their attempt by understanding the need to stretch out the anchors using the small boat. The sailors' intention was to secure themselves, believing the ship to be in grave danger despite the anchors already cast out. St. Paul's wisdom prevented them from perishing in a reckless and uncertain escape.

The officers of the ship, possibly detected by St. Luke's nautical skill, attempted an unworthy escape by pretending to carry anchors ahead of the ship. However, St. Paul's shrewdness and understanding of the need to stretch out the anchors in front using the small boat exposed their true intentions. Despite their pretext of securing the ship, they believed it was in imminent danger and sought refuge on land. St. Paul's sagacity prevented a hasty and uncertain escape, ensuring the safety of all aboard.

The officers of the ship, possibly detected by St. Luke's nautical skill, attempted an unworthy escape by pretending to carry anchors ahead of the ship. However, St. Paul's understanding and vigilance saw through their pretext. He knew that stretching out or laying out the anchors in front required the use of the small boat, which contradicted their supposed need for security. Despite their feigned intention to protect the ship, their true purpose was to flee from what they believed to be imminent danger, which St. Paul wisely averted.
